Certification Exam

  • Show All Code
  • Hide All Code
  • View Source
R
PowerBI
analysis
Published

June 23, 2024

As part of the certified data analyst exam by DataCamp, I completed a two-hour exam testing my R and SQL skills, followed by a four-hour practical exam where I analyzed sales data from a stationary shop.

The goal of the analysis was to determine the best-performing marketing method following the launch of new products. Additionally, I identified high-paying and loyal customers to prioritize them in the marketing strategy for future product launches. Here are some examples but the full report can be found here.

Analysis was conduct with following components:

  1. Data Cleaning and Validation

  2. Exploratory Analysis

  3. Key Business Metric Identification

  4. Recommendation

  5. Presentation (12 min, video)

Code 
# Load packages
library(readr)
library(tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)

setwd("C:/Users/udwal/Documents/Studies_Viadrina/Becoming Data Fluent/Fluent2024/Bonus Assignment/Portfolio")

# Importing data
data <- read_csv("product_sales.csv")

#  Checking uneque customer IDs
num_unique_customers <- length(unique(data$customer_id))

# Checking column unique categorical values 
unique_methods <- unique(data$sales_method)

# fixing typos
typo_dict <- c(
  "em + call" = "Email + Call",
  "email" = "Email")

data <- data %>%
  mutate(sales_method = coalesce(typo_dict[sales_method], sales_method))

# Cehcking after fixing typos
unique_methods <- unique(data$sales_method)
print(unique_methods)

unique_product_count <- unique(data$nb_sold)

# Revenue has only 7% missing data and hence droppping NAs
data_clean <- data %>% filter(!is.na(revenue))

# values should not exceed 40 and hence filtering
data_clean <- data_clean %>% 
    filter(!years_as_customer > 40)

# site visits
summary(data_clean$nb_site_visits)

unique_state <- unique(data_clean$state)
print(unique_state)
Code 
library(RColorBrewer)

pastel_colors <- brewer.pal(6, "Pastel2")

ggplot(data_clean, aes(x = as.factor(week), y = revenue, fill = sales_method)) +
  geom_col(position = "dodge") +
  scale_fill_manual(values = pastel_colors) +
  labs(x = "Week", y = "Revenue", fill = "Sales Method") +
  ggtitle("Revenue by Week and Sales Method") +
  theme_minimal()
Code 
ggplot(data_clean, aes(y = revenue)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  labs(y = "Revenue") +
  ggtitle("Revenue Distribution") +
  theme_minimal()
Code 
# Filter high-revenue customers (above 200.00)
high_rev_cust <- data_clean %>%
  filter(revenue > 200.00)

# Aggregate data by state
data_aggregated <- high_rev_cust %>%
  group_by(state) %>%
  summarise(total_revenue = sum(revenue, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%
  ungroup()

# Sort data by total_revenue in descending order
data_aggregated <- data_aggregated %>%
  arrange(desc(total_revenue))

# Reorder state factor levels based on total_revenue
data_aggregated$state <- factor(data_aggregated$state, levels = data_aggregated$state)

ggplot(data_aggregated, aes(x = "", y = state, fill = total_revenue)) +
  geom_tile() +
  scale_fill_gradient(low = "white", high = "orange", name = "Total Revenue") +
  labs(x = "State", y = NULL, fill = "Total Revenue") +
  ggtitle("Total Revenue by State for High Value Customers") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    axis.text.y = element_text(size = 6)
  )
Source Code
---
title: "Certification Exam"
date: "2024-06-23"
categories: [R, PowerBI, analysis]
image: "certificate.jpg"
---

As part of the certified data analyst exam by DataCamp, I completed a two-hour exam testing my R and SQL skills, followed by a four-hour practical exam where I analyzed sales data from a stationary shop.

The goal of the analysis was to determine the best-performing marketing method following the launch of new products. Additionally, I identified high-paying and loyal customers to prioritize them in the marketing strategy for future product launches. Here are some examples but the full report can be found [here](https://www.datacamp.com/datalab/w/efdedffd-1df1-4b55-be0e-4c7c6ed91eb7).

Analysis was conduct with following components:

1.  Data Cleaning and Validation

2.  Exploratory Analysis

3.  Key Business Metric Identification

4.  Recommendation

5.  Presentation (12 min, video)

```{r data cleaning}
#| echo: true
#| results: hide
#| warning: false
#| message: false

# Load packages
library(readr)
library(tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)

setwd("C:/Users/udwal/Documents/Studies_Viadrina/Becoming Data Fluent/Fluent2024/Bonus Assignment/Portfolio")

# Importing data
data <- read_csv("product_sales.csv")

#  Checking uneque customer IDs
num_unique_customers <- length(unique(data$customer_id))

# Checking column unique categorical values 
unique_methods <- unique(data$sales_method)

# fixing typos
typo_dict <- c(
  "em + call" = "Email + Call",
  "email" = "Email")

data <- data %>%
  mutate(sales_method = coalesce(typo_dict[sales_method], sales_method))

# Cehcking after fixing typos
unique_methods <- unique(data$sales_method)
print(unique_methods)

unique_product_count <- unique(data$nb_sold)

# Revenue has only 7% missing data and hence droppping NAs
data_clean <- data %>% filter(!is.na(revenue))

# values should not exceed 40 and hence filtering
data_clean <- data_clean %>% 
    filter(!years_as_customer > 40)

# site visits
summary(data_clean$nb_site_visits)

unique_state <- unique(data_clean$state)
print(unique_state)
```

```{r Method comparison}
#| echo: true
#| results: hide
#| warning: false
#| message: false

library(RColorBrewer)

pastel_colors <- brewer.pal(6, "Pastel2")

ggplot(data_clean, aes(x = as.factor(week), y = revenue, fill = sales_method)) +
  geom_col(position = "dodge") +
  scale_fill_manual(values = pastel_colors) +
  labs(x = "Week", y = "Revenue", fill = "Sales Method") +
  ggtitle("Revenue by Week and Sales Method") +
  theme_minimal()
```

```{r Revenue distribution}
#| echo: true
#| results: hide
#| warning: false
#| message: false
ggplot(data_clean, aes(y = revenue)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  labs(y = "Revenue") +
  ggtitle("Revenue Distribution") +
  theme_minimal()
```

```{r Location of high value customers}
#| echo: true
#| results: hide
#| warning: false
#| message: false

# Filter high-revenue customers (above 200.00)
high_rev_cust <- data_clean %>%
  filter(revenue > 200.00)

# Aggregate data by state
data_aggregated <- high_rev_cust %>%
  group_by(state) %>%
  summarise(total_revenue = sum(revenue, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%
  ungroup()

# Sort data by total_revenue in descending order
data_aggregated <- data_aggregated %>%
  arrange(desc(total_revenue))

# Reorder state factor levels based on total_revenue
data_aggregated$state <- factor(data_aggregated$state, levels = data_aggregated$state)

ggplot(data_aggregated, aes(x = "", y = state, fill = total_revenue)) +
  geom_tile() +
  scale_fill_gradient(low = "white", high = "orange", name = "Total Revenue") +
  labs(x = "State", y = NULL, fill = "Total Revenue") +
  ggtitle("Total Revenue by State for High Value Customers") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    axis.text.y = element_text(size = 6)
  )
```
